Introduction

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare but potentially life-threatening disorder characterized by a hypermetabolic response to volatile anesthetics and depolarizing muscle relaxants.  Most cases arise shortly after induction or during maintenance of anesthesia in susceptible individuals.  A genetic defect in skeletal muscle receptors causes sustained muscle contraction, which can lead to hypercarbia, metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and hyperthermia.  Malignant hyperthermia is a clinical diagnosis that requires immediate treatment with dantrolene (a muscle relaxant), along with supportive measures (eg, cooling), to prevent death.

Risk factors



  • Genetic predisposition:  Autosomal dominant genetic mutation causes abnormal ryanodine receptors (RYR1) in the skeletal muscle (
    figure 1
    )
  • Anesthetic exposure:  This is the main trigger for malignant hyperthermia in susceptible patients.  It involves volatile anesthetics (eg, halothane, isoflurane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (eg, succinylcholine)

Pathophysiology



Malignant hyperthermia occurs in patients with genetically abnormal ryanodine receptors (RYR1) in the skeletal muscle.  On exposure to certain anesthetic agents (typically succinylcholine and inhalational gases), these defective receptors allow the unregulated passage of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the intracellular space.  As a result of excessive calcium accumulation, patients develop sudden-onset, widespread muscle rigidity, which is often first noted in the masseter.



The widespread, sustained muscle contraction (which is pathognomonic for malignant hyperthermia) creates a hypermetabolic cellular state, which results in:



  • Excessive CO2 production:  hypercarbia and respiratory acidosis
  • Depletion of cellular oxygen:  anaerobic metabolism, lactic acid production, and metabolic acidosis
  • Rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown):  release of creatinine kinase and myoglobin into blood, which can lead to acute kidney injury
  • Hyperthermia:  increased cellular metabolism that overwhelms the body's ability to dissipate heat

Clinical presentation



Clinical signs of malignant hyperthermia classically develop shortly after the administration of general anesthesia but can occur at any time during the intraoperative or postoperative periods.  Patients may exhibit any combination of the following signs (most do not have all):



  • Hypercarbia with tachypnea:  often the earliest sign, detected by a sudden rise in end-tidal CO2, does not improve by increasing minute ventilation (eg, tidal volume, rate)
  • Widespread skeletal muscle contraction and rigidity:  particularly involving the jaw (masseter muscle spasm)
  • Sinus tachycardia:  due to a hypermetabolic state
  • Metabolic acidosis:  related to increased lactic acid production
  • Myoglobinuria:  muscle breakdown that releases myoglobin, which causes red/brown urine
  • Hyperkalemia:  potassium released from damaged skeletal muscle cells (may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest)
  • Hyperthermia:  possibly a late manifestation

Differential diagnosis



  • Septic shock:  may present with elevated temperature, tachycardia, and metabolic acidosis, but diffuse muscle rigidity is not expected.  An infectious source (not anesthesia) is often identified as the inciting factor.
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome:  an adverse reaction to antipsychotic medications and is characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, and altered mental status.  It can be distinguished from malignant hyperthermia by the clinical context (no anesthetic exposure).
  • Thyrotoxicosis:  thyroid storm can be precipitated by surgery and cause hyperthermia and tachycardia, but it does not cause sustained muscle rigidity.  Elevated levels of T3 and T4 confirm the diagnosis.
  • Serotonin syndrome:  may cause hyperpyrexia, tachycardia, and tachypnea but classically presents with hyperreflexia and clonus rather than rigidity.  It is seen in patients taking serotonergic medications.

Diagnosis



Malignant hyperthermia is a clinical diagnosis that should be strongly suspected in any patient who develops unexpected hypercarbia, sudden muscle rigidity, unexplained metabolic acidosis, and/or hyperthermia during or after anesthesia.  Diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion because the timing of onset and constellation of clinical signs can vary from patient to patient.

Laboratory evaluation



Acute malignant hyperthermia is mainly a clinical diagnosis, but certain laboratory findings are characteristic and support the diagnosis.  The following tests are recommended when malignant hyperthermia is suspected:



  • Serum electrolytes:  Classic findings include hyperkalemia and a low bicarbonate level (reflecting acidosis).
  • Arterial blood gas:  Low pH and elevated lactate levels can be used to identify and quantify the severity of respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
  • Serum myoglobin and creatine kinase:  High levels reflect muscle damage and can lead to acute kidney injury.
  • Urine myoglobin:  Myoglobin in the urine is consistent with acute muscle injury.

Management



Immediate intervention is critical to prevent mortality.  Any patient who receives anesthesia and then exhibits a sudden rise in end-tidal CO2, muscle rigidity, rising temperature, or other characteristic signs, without a convincing alternate diagnosis, should be emergently treated for malignant hyperthermia.  This includes:



  • Prompt discontinuation of triggering agents (eg, anesthetics, depolarizing muscle relaxants)
  • Immediate administration of dantrolene, the antidote of choice and skeletal muscle relaxant that directly inhibits calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  • Initiate supportive care, including cooling, electrolyte correction (eg, bicarbonate for acidosis), ventilatory support (eg, 100% oxygen, hyperventilation), and IV fluids (to prevent rhabdomyolysis-induced kidney injury)

Prevention



Prior to receiving anesthetic agents, patients with a family history or previous suspected episode of malignant hyperthermia should have further diagnostic testing.  The gold standard for testing for malignant hyperthermia susceptibility is the caffeine-halothane contracture test, which exposes biopsied muscles to halothane and caffeine to assess contracture response.  In addition, genetic testing for ryanodine receptor (RYR1) mutations can determine a predisposition to this condition, but neither evaluation is helpful in an acute crisis.  Susceptible individuals should be advised to avoid triggering agents and undergo proper preoperative precautions to prevent malignant hyperthermia in the future.

Prognosis



The prognosis of malignant hyperthermia is generally favorable with rapid diagnosis and treatment.  However, failure to identify or aggressively manage the condition can lead to severe complications, including arrhythmia, cardiac arrest, and renal failure, as well as death.  The expanded use of end-tidal CO2 detectors and core (rather than skin) temperature monitoring during anesthesia has enhanced early detection and improved mortality.

Summary
